Good sons! What are the ten universal bases of bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas? They are

earth universal base, water universal base, fire universal base, wind universal base, space universal base, blue universal base, yellow universal base, red universal base, white universal base, and consciousness universal base. These are called the ten universal bases.

If this bodhisattva wishes to include all realms in one realm, then all realms are included in one realm, namely, the earth realm;ğŸ”½If he wishes to include all realms in one realm, then all realms are included in one realm, namely, the water realm;
If he wishes to include all realms in one realm, then all realms are included in one realm, namely, the fire realm;
If one wishes to make all realms enter one realm, they enter one realm, namely the wind realm;

If one wishes to make all realms enter one realm, they enter one realm, namely the space realm;ğŸ”½If one wishes to make all entrances enter one entrance, they enter one entrance, namely the blue entrance;
If one wishes to make all entrances enter one entrance, they enter one entrance, namely the yellow entrance;
If one wishes to make all entrances enter one entrance, they enter one entrance, namely the red entrance;
If one wishes to make all entrances enter one entrance, they enter one entrance, namely the white entrance;
If one wishes to make all entrances enter one entrance, they enter one entrance, namely the consciousness entrance.

If one wishes to make all earth, water, fire, wind, space, blue, yellow, red, white, and consciousness entrances enter one entrance, they enter one entrance. Therefore, it is called 'all entrances entering one.'
One entrance immediately becomes all entrances, therefore it is called all entrances.
These are called the ten all-entrances of the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva.
Good sons!
What are the ten masteries of the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva?

Namely, mastery over life, mastery over mind, mastery over objects, mastery over karma, mastery over birth, mastery over spiritual powers, mastery over faith, mastery over vows, mastery over wisdom, and mastery over the Dharma. These are called the ten masteries of the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva.
Good sons!
Attaining the supreme nectar is called mastery over life;
Being able to know that all is only one mind is called mastery over mind;
Producing various precious treasures from the palm and also taking the sky as a treasury is called mastery over objects;
Being far removed from all afflictions, the habitual tendencies of afflictions, and the influence of ignorance is called mastery over karma;
Being able to freely turn back from dhyÄna, concentration, liberation, samÄdhi, and samÄpatti is called the mastery of birth;
Naturally practicing all practices is called the mastery of the mind;
Attaining mastery in observing all samÄdhis is called the mastery of faith;
At the moment of giving rise to the mind, accomplishing all matters in the present is called the mastery of vows;
All bodily, verbal, and mental actions are based on wisdom, which is called the mastery of wisdom;
Manifesting the equality of the true suchness of dharmas, the ultimate truth, and stainless wisdom is called the mastery of the Dharma.
Moreover, good man!
Attaining the mastery of life, one can counteract all worldly fears of death;
Attaining the mastery of mind, one can counteract all worldly afflictions and fears;
Attaining the mastery of wealth, one can counteract all worldly fears of poverty;
Because of attaining mastery over karma, one can counteract the fear of all worldly evil conduct;
Because of attaining mastery over birth, one can counteract the fear of all worldly evil destinies;

Because of attaining mastery over the mind, one can counteract the fear of all worldly pursuits;ğŸ”½Because of attaining mastery over faith, one can counteract the fear of all worldly offenses of slandering the Dharma;
Because of attaining mastery over vows, one can counteract the fear of all worldly mental bonds;
Because of attaining mastery over wisdom, one can counteract the fear of all worldly doubts and afflictions;
Because of attaining mastery over the Dharma, one can counteract the fear of all worldly great assemblies.
Moreover, good man!
Abstaining from the offense of killing, being free from anger and harm towards all beings, is the cause for attaining mastery over life;
Great compassion that is unobstructed towards joyful beings, and great compassion that is unobstructed towards suffering beings, is the cause for attaining mastery over the mind;
The cause of mastery over things is to give up all things with an impartial mind and to dedicate them to great enlightenment.
The cause of mastery over karma is to engage in all activities, namely, pure physical, verbal, and mental actions.
The cause of mastery over rebirth is to take up all wholesome roots and the ten wholesome courses of action, with the mind of enlightenment as the basis.
The cause of mastery over wishes is to give elephants, horses, carriages, and vehicles to sentient beings with offerings, respect, prostrations, and praise.
The cause of mastery over faith is to teach and transform all sentient beings in the Three Jewels.
The cause of mastery over vows is to give all sentient beings pure physical, verbal, and mental actions.
The cause of mastery over wisdom is to be free from greed for offerings, respect, food and drink, and to be able to give the Dharma to all sentient beings.

Equally teaching and transforming all sentient beings, speaking of the equality of the Dharma realm of all sentient beings, speaking of all sentient beings and all buddhas and tathÄgatas as the Dharma body, not the body of food and drink, this is the cause of mastery of the Dharma.
This is called the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva attaining the ten masteries.
Good man!
What are the ten truths of the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva?

Namely, the truth of the world, the truth of ultimate meaning, the truth of characteristics, the truth of distinctions, the truth of contemplation, the truth of events, the truth of arising, the truth of the knowledge of the exhaustion of defilements and non-production of new ones, the truth of the knowledge of entering the path, and the truth of accumulating the knowledge of the tathÄgatas. These are called the ten truths.
Good man!
The truth of the world means limited names and numbers spoken for the sake of others, narrow and inferior, not extensive. This is called the truth of the world.

The ultimate truth is the extremely profound emptiness, the corresponding Dharma, which is without limit, without cessation, not caused by others, of a single equal characteristic, without high or low, with the characteristic of neither disturbance nor stillness, the true characteristic of all dharmas. This is called the ultimate truth.

The characteristic truth is the characteristic of suffering for those who are oppressed, the characteristic of accumulation for those who are born, the characteristic of cessation for those who are purified, and the characteristic of the path for those who ride it. This is called the characteristic truth.

Furthermore, good sons!ğŸ”½Knowing the characteristic of no-self in the nature of all dharmas, the characteristic of realizing the path, and the characteristic of realizing it, this is called the characteristic truth.

Thus, knowing the characteristic of purity in the nature of all dharmas, knowing the characteristic of natural detachment, knowing the characteristic of natural emptiness, knowing the characteristic of non-arising and non-cessation in the nature of all dharmas, the characteristic of realizing the path, and the characteristic of realizing the path, this is called the characteristic truth.

The truth of distinctions means that all dharmas are of one characteristic, but are distinguished based on other causes and conditions. The one characteristic is called the characteristic of emptiness, which is distinguished based on that emptiness.

Moreover, all dharmas are without characteristics, without vows, without activity, unborn, and unceasing. All those distinctions are characteristics of emptiness, all are empty, and are characteristics of non-opposition. This is called the truth of distinctions.
What is the truth of contemplation?
Contemplation means penetrating contemplation, repeatedly seeing, contemplating, knowing, seeing, awakening, and realizing wisdom. Not opposing those objects is called the truth of contemplation.

The truth of phenomena means the wisdom of phenomena. Phenomena refer to the aggregates, realms, and sense bases. Knowing those aggregates, realms, and sense bases are only born from causes and conditions, without phenomena, and without a life-force, one is able to know this and realize the path. This is called the truth of phenomena.
What is the truth of arising?ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:

Namely, relying on that knowledge to eliminate afflictions, relying on that practice to eliminate afflictions, relying on that path to eliminate afflictions, and attaining the ten powers, four fearlessnesses, and eighteen distinctive abilities of a buddha, and further realizing all dharmas and attaining the supreme sovereign dharmas of all tathÄgatas, this is called the truth of arising.

The truth of the knowledge of exhaustion and non-arising means speaking of the exhaustion of all conditioned dharmas. The exhaustion of those conditioned dharmas is neither exhausted nor inexhaustible.
If exhaustion were exhaustible, then there would be exhaustion of exhaustion. Therefore, exhaustion is not exhausted.
Therefore, exhaustion does not arise or cease. This is called the truth of the knowledge of exhaustion and non-arising.
What is the truth of the knowledge of entering the path?

By what kind of knowledge, by what kind of path, by what kind of accumulation of merit and virtue, and by what kind of accumulation of knowledge, knowing that all dharmas are unborn and unceasing, relying on those dharmas oneself and causing others to enter, this is called the truth of the knowledge of entering the path.
What is the truth of the knowledge of gathering the tathÄgatas?

That is, between the Cloud of Dharma ground and the TathÄgata ground, gathering the wisdom of the TathÄgata, attaining that natural path, and realizing the wisdom of the TathÄgata, this is called the truth of gathering the wisdom of the TathÄgata.
These are called the ten truths of the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva.
Good man!
What are the nine successive concentrations of the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva?

The bodhisattva-mahÄsattva, apart from desires and evil and unwholesome states, with thought and investigation, enters the practice of the first concentration with joy and pleasure born of separation.
Good man!
Apart from desires means the dharmas of love and attachment that are opposed to the first concentration. Being apart from those dharmas is called apart from desires.

Apart from evil and unwholesome states means killing, stealing, sexual misconduct, false speech, divisive speech, harsh speech, frivolous speech, greed, and wrong views that arise due to greed, hatred, and delusion. These are called evil and unwholesome states. Being apart from those dharmas is called the first concentration.
With perception means being accompanied by perception.
What is perception?
What is the object?
In accordance with the first dhyÄna, perception has various other names, such as knowledge, perception, contemplation, concentration, and so forth. This is called perception.
What is investigation?
That very investigation of the practice of perception in accordance with the first dhyÄna, contemplating and receiving the knowledge of concentration, is called investigation.

Based on the practice of disgust, accompanied by that perception and investigation, one accomplishes the first dhyÄna. Based on the practice of disgust, accompanied by that joy and bliss, one accomplishes the first dhyÄna. This is called entering the practice of the first dhyÄna with joy and bliss.
Practice refers to receiving, protecting, and recollecting joy, bliss, knowledge, and so forth. This is called practice.

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas dwelling in the first dhyÄna attain the supreme desire for the acceptance of the non-arising of dharmas. Therefore, they enter dhyÄna seeking the acceptance of the non-arising of dharmas.

This bodhisattva-mahÄsattva, in order to attain the unsurpassed forbearance of the non-arising of dharmas, gives rise to an unstable mind within that first dhyÄna. Therefore, the bodhisattva abandons that first dhyÄna and seeks the second dhyÄna.

This bodhisattva, apart from that first dhyÄna with its mind of initial and sustained thought, extinguishes that mind, separates from that mind, purifies that mind, and calms that mind, in order to enter the second dhyÄna and in order to accomplish the practice of the second dhyÄna.

This bodhisattva, apart from those initial and sustained thoughts, with an internally purified mind, single-minded, without initial thought, without sustained thought, gives rise to joy and bliss, and enters the practice of the second dhyÄna.
Internally purified refers to the antidote that counters the dharmas that obstruct the second dhyÄna.
The bodhisattva is tranquil, and those dharmas are pure and untainted, which is called internally purified.
Single-minded refers to extinguishing all initial and sustained thoughts of the first dhyÄna, and being tranquil and of one taste, just like the great ocean.
Good man!
It is like all the waters of the world entering the great ocean and becoming of one taste, namely, the taste of salt.

In the same way, the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva enters the second concentration, extinguishing all the thoughts and contemplations of the first concentration, with a single taste of tranquility, without thought or contemplation. This is called attaining the samÄdhi of no thought and no contemplation.

This bodhisattva, relying on that concentration, gives rise to joy - namely, a joyful mind towards the Buddha, Dharma, and Saá¹ƒgha - and relying on that joyful mind, all wholesome merits are naturally fulfilled.

This bodhisattva, for the sake of the superior light of the acceptance of the non-arising of dharmas, the ever-increasing light, the ever-increasing excellence, and the ever-increasing softness, attains a superior desire.

This bodhisattva, relying on the superior desire of the acceptance of the non-arising of dharmas, does not abide in or delight in the second concentration, but further seeks the practice of the third concentration, which is superior.

This bodhisattva gives rise to this thought: 'Knowing that the mind of joy obstructs the third dhyÄna and obstructs the acceptance of non-arising of dharmas, therefore the bodhisattva, leaving behind joy, practices equanimity, mindfulness, and wisdom, and experiences the bliss of the body - this bliss is spoken of by the sages and is also abandoned - far from the bliss of joy, enters the practice of the third dhyÄna.'
This bodhisattva attains the bliss of samÄdhi, is disgusted with that joy, and gives rise to this thought:
'This bliss without joy is impermanent bliss, it is a dharma of exhaustion and cessation, it is not permanent, not eternal, not true bliss, not ultimate bliss.'
Having known this, the bodhisattva further attains the superior desire for the acceptance of the non-arising of dharmas.

'This bodhisattva, relying on the superior desire for the acceptance of the non-arising of dharmas, does not delight in suffering or bliss. This bodhisattva, leaving behind suffering and bliss, first eliminates sorrow and joy, neither suffering nor blissful, with equanimity and pure mindfulness, enters the practice of the fourth dhyÄna.'

This bodhisattva attains the fourth dhyÄna samÄdhi, with a supple mind, a self-mastered mind, a tranquil mind, a bright mind, an upright mind, and with all those pleasant things, he gives them to all sentient beings.
When this bodhisattva gives present peace and happiness to all sentient beings, he immediately attains the light of the acceptance of the non-arising of dharmas.
Because this bodhisattva attains the light of the acceptance of the non-arising of dharmas, his practice becomes swift.

This bodhisattva, in that supremely pleasant fourth dhyÄna, does not give rise to a mind of pleasure, he abandons that pleasure, and with pure mindfulness and recollection, only sees the appearance of space before him.

This bodhisattva, having transcended all forms, having extinguished all opposing characteristics, not thinking of various characteristics, knowing the limitless space, enters the practice of limitless space.
This bodhisattva observes forms in this way, generally speaking, there are two kinds:
First, the four great elements; second, that which relies on the four great elements.
The four great elements refer to earth, water, fire, and wind;
The dependent four great elements refer to form, smell, taste, and touch.
There are thus eight kinds of form in total, apart from which there are no other forms.
Because they eliminate the characteristics of form, it is said to transcend all characteristics of form.
Whatever dharmas have the characteristics of form, those dharmas must have the characteristic of obstruction.
Therefore, transcending all characteristics of form, eliminating all characteristics of obstruction, not thinking, not engaging in various different characteristics,
Because of transcending various different characteristics, because of not thinking of various different characteristics, one only sees the characteristic of space.
Therefore, the bodhisattva knows immeasurable space and thus enters the practice of infinite space.
This bodhisattva, entering the samÄdhi of the sphere of infinite space, gives rise to the following thought:
'Space is boundless, space has no limit, space has no edge. Whatever dharmas are boundless, etc., those dharmas have no prior limit, no middle limit, no posterior limit.'
Thus, one contemplates all dharmas as having no prior, middle, or posterior limit.

This bodhisattva enters such samÄdhi, and immediately gives rise to the mind of great kindness towards all sentient beings. He immediately attains the wisdom of equality towards all dharmas, which manifests before him. At that time, the bodhisattva begins to attain the light of superior progress within the forbearance of the non-arising of dharmas.

This bodhisattva surpasses all the characteristics of boundless space, and directly knows the characteristics of boundless consciousness. He enters the practice of the stage of boundless consciousness.
This bodhisattva gives rise to such a thought:
'These characteristics of boundless space are merely conceptual distinctions of consciousness.'
This bodhisattva attains such a mind and knows that all are merely characteristics of consciousness, and this consciousness is immeasurable and boundless.
This bodhisattva enters such samÄdhi and attains the forbearance of the non-arising of dharmas, but it is not the ultimate accomplishment of the forbearance of the non-arising of dharmas.
This bodhisattva surpasses the realm of boundless consciousness and directly knows the realm of nothingness. He enters the practice of the realm of nothingness and no small realm.
As for nothingness, it is the absence of that which exists.
What is that which exists?
It refers to the various discriminations of greed, anger, and delusion, the false discriminations, and the various discriminations. All conditioned dharmas arise from the false discriminating mind.
Because there is no that which exists, it is said to be nothingness.
As for no small, as explained above, the small characteristics, subtle characteristics, and minute characteristics within the dharmas are called small characteristics.
Because there are no those small characteristics, it is said to be no small.
Because it surpasses all coarse and subtle characteristics, it is said to be nothingness and no small.

This bodhisattva, abiding in such a samÄdhi, attains the light of the forbearance of the non-arising of dharmas that is even more excellent and appears before him.ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:

This bodhisattva, having attained the acceptance of the non-arising of dharmas, does not delight in that samÄdhi of nothing whatsoever or of little, but seeks for a superior samÄdhi and gives rise to a superior aspiration.
This bodhisattva, seeking for a superior samÄdhi and superior practice, gives rise to this thought:
'This characteristic of nothing whatsoever or of little is also a subtle characteristic, because it is falsely discriminated.'
Next, he contemplates neither characteristics nor the absence of characteristics.
What dharmas are neither characteristics nor the absence of characteristics?
Characteristics are emptiness, and the absence of characteristics arises from causes and conditions.

At that time, the bodhisattva attains the samÄdhi of neither characteristics nor the absence of characteristics, and surpasses the stage of nothing whatsoever, entering the samÄdhi of neither perception nor non-perception.
The bodhisattva, abiding in that stage, gives rise to this thought:
'That stage of neither perception nor non-perception is not delightful.'
This bodhisattva then departs from that stage.
This bodhisattva, having departed from those places, immediately all dharmas not arising and not ceasing manifest.

This bodhisattva knows all dharmas do not arise and do not cease, and sees all dharmas with the nature of quiescence. This bodhisattva does not practice or abide. At that time, the bodhisattva attains the supreme, pure acceptance of the non-arising of dharmas.
This bodhisattva from here on attains the spontaneous, unceasing bodhisattva path.
This is called the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva's nine kinds of sequential entry into samÄdhi.
Good sons!
What are the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva's ten powers?

Namely, the power of faith, the power of the inner [mind], the power of practice, the power of forbearance, the power of wisdom, the power of separation, the power of hearing and understanding, the power of eloquent explanation, the power of merit, and the power of practicing in accordance with reality.
Good sons!
What is the power of faith?
The power of faith means that bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas have faith in various dharmas, and in accordance with their minds, they attain the power of faith.
Within this power of faith, all the worlds, devas, humans, and mÄras are unable to disturb them. This is called the power of faith of the bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas.
Good sons!
What is the inner power of the bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas?
When the bodhisattva gives rise to a greedy mind, he cultivates the contemplation of impurity to extinguish the greedy mind;
when he gives rise to an angry mind, he cultivates great kindness to extinguish the angry mind;
when he gives rise to a deluded mind, he cultivates the practice of causes and conditions to extinguish the deluded mind.
If the bodhisattva is scolded, beaten, or bound by others, he gives rise to this thought:
'This sound is like an echo, and scolding, etc. is like a dream.'

At that time, the bodhisattva attains the wisdom of equality and faithfully knows that being beaten, scolded, bound, etc. is only his own karma. Being able to see in this way immediately extinguishes it.

This bodhisattva knows that within this body there are various things such as afflictions, cutting, and so forth, like the moon in water. At that time, the bodhisattva attains the wisdom of equality and is able to know and immediately eliminate them.
In brief, the bodhisattva is able to know that all the gates of afflictions are gates of purity. This is called the inner power of the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva.
Good man!
What is the power of practice of the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva?

It refers to the power of the stage of faith and the power of the stage of seeing the path, which counteracts the Dharma of obstacles. Those Dharma of obstacles are unable to obstruct this bodhisattva.

In the stage of faith and the stage of seeing the path, all the worldly gods, humans, demons, and BrahmÄs are unable to disturb him. This is called the power of practice of the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva.
Good man!
What is the power of patience of the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva?

If a bodhisattva is scolded by others but does not retaliate, it is because he has attained the power of wisdom that realizes the equality of echoes;ğŸ”½If a bodhisattva is beaten by others but does not retaliate, it is because he has attained the power of wisdom that realizes the equality of reflections;
If a bodhisattva is harmed by others but does not retaliate, it is because he has attained the power of wisdom that realizes the equality of illusions;
If a bodhisattva is angered by others but does not retaliate, it is because he has attained the power of wisdom that realizes the equality of inner purity;
The eight worldly dharmas cannot defile him, because he has attained the power of wisdom that realizes the equality of the purity of worldly dharmas;
All afflictions cannot defile or overcome him, because he has attained the power of wisdom that realizes the equality of the causes and conditions of accumulation.
In brief, this bodhisattva sees that all defiled dharmas are gates to purity. This is called the power of patience of a bodhisattva-mahÄsattva.
Good man!
What is the power of wisdom of a bodhisattva-mahÄsattva?
That is to say, the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva knows that the aggregates, realms, and sense-fields are empty, unborn, and unceasing. With what kind of wisdom can one accumulate great enlightenment?

Within that wisdom, all mÄras, non-Buddhists, and those with wrong views, even if they appear in the form of the Buddha, cannot move it, disturb it, or cause it to doubt. This is called the power of wisdom of the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva.
Good sons!
What is the power of detachment of the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva?

If the body of a bodhisattva abides in one place, and all sentient beings come to the bodhisattva, speak evil words, slander the bodhisattva, also slander the Buddha, Dharma, and Saá¹ƒgha treasures, or even seize the bodhisattva, cut him, or slice him, at that time the bodhisattva does not give rise to a mind of harm or anger towards those sentient beings, nor does he give rise to a mind of afflictions, habitual tendencies, or afflictions.

If there are sentient beings who come to transform the bodhisattva to give rise to various evils, the bodhisattva at that time transforms them to follow himself, and they attain a firm mind in the Three Jewels. This is called the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva's separation from power.
Good man!
What is the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva's power of hearing wisdom?
Good man!
The bodhisattva-mahÄsattva is a sea treasury of much hearing, upholding what is heard, and the accumulation of the wisdom of hearing. The bodhisattva accomplishes such a power of much hearing wisdom.

If the sentient beings of the trichiliocosm bring various doubts to the bodhisattva, asking questions simultaneously, each different, at that time the bodhisattva's mind is unmoved, and with one voice he answers, cutting off all doubts.
Thus, for hundreds of thousands of myriads of kalpas, with various questions, the bodhisattva answers with one voice at one time. This is called the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva's power of hearing wisdom.
Good man!
What is the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva's power of delight in speaking?

The bodhisattva, while expounding the Dharma in the midst of a great assembly of hundreds of thousands of myriads of koá¹­is of people, without thinking or discriminating what kind of sentient beings delight in what kind of Dharma, the bodhisattva expounds the Dharma according to those sentient beings.

The bodhisattva expounds the Dharma without losing the meaning of the words, does not speak repeatedly, does not speak slowly or quickly, does not speak with an unpleasant voice, and does not speak too much or too little. This is called the power of eloquent expression of the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva.
Good man!
What is the power of merit of the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva?

If the bodhisattva is under a tree, in his own dwelling, or in an empty place, all mÄras and their retinues who come to that bodhisattva to destroy and disturb him, those mÄras and their retinues are unable to destroy and disturb the bodhisattva's practice.
Those mÄras will be frightened themselves, destroyed, scattered, and crushed, with no one to save them.

The weapons held by those demons, such as swords, spears, long hooks, axes, fighting wheels, lassos, bows and arrows, halberds, and so forth, were like clouds and rain, but due to the power of the merits of that bodhisattva-mahÄsattva, they instantly transformed into various kinds of flowers, namely, mandÄra flowers, great mandÄra flowers, luocha flowers, great luocha flowers, tÄra flowers, great tÄra flowers, campaka flowers, sumnÄ flowers, utpala flowers, padma flowers, and so forth. Such various kinds of flowers rained down like clouds as offerings to the bodhisattva.
The various kinds of coarse and frightening words spoken by those demons, due to the power of the merits of that bodhisattva, instantly transformed into various kinds of praises and subtle sounds.
At that time, the bodhisattva, due to the power of his merits, causes the various coarse and evil six sense objects of those mÄras to disappear and not appear.

At that time, the bodhisattva, according to his thoughts, causes all wonderful sense objects to appear in the sky before him. This bodhisattva, relying on the superior causes and conditions of his own merits, takes the sky as his treasury. In the palm of his hand, he accomplishes all supreme wealth and treasures, causing all sentient beings to enjoy them. The supreme and wonderful treasures in the bodhisattva's palm are all accomplished by the power of his own merits.
Good man!
If one were to speak of the power of this bodhisattva's merits for the duration of an eon, it would be inexhaustible. This is called the power of merits of a bodhisattva-mahÄsattva.
Good man!
What is the power of a bodhisattva-mahÄsattva's practice in accordance with reality?
Good man!
There are ten kinds of power of a bodhisattva-mahÄsattva's practice in accordance with reality.
What are the ten?

Namely, the power of practicing giving, the power of practicing precepts, the power of practicing patience, the power of practicing diligence, the power of practicing meditation, the power of practicing wisdom, the power of practicing skillful means, the power of practicing vows, the power of practicing strength, and the power of practicing cognition. These are called the ten kinds of powers of practicing in accordance with reality associated with the perfections of bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas.
Good man!
All the other immeasurable powers of practicing in accordance with reality of bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas are all included within these ten kinds of powers of practicing in accordance with reality.
Good man!
What is the power of practicing giving of bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas?
Good man!
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas do not have a single thing that they are stingy with and do not give away;
Only excluding those things that harm and injure sentient beings.

The mind of giving that a bodhisattva can practice in any way, that mind of giving can only be believed by all sentient beings except the buddhas, tathÄgatas, and bodhisattvas who have attained forbearance. How much less can they understand?
This is called the power of practice of giving by a bodhisattva.
Good man!
What is the power of practice of upholding precepts by a bodhisattva?
Good man!
There are ten kinds of power of practice of upholding precepts by a bodhisattva.
What are the ten?

Namely, the practice of upholding precepts by Å›rÄvakas, the practice of upholding precepts by pratyekabuddhas, the practice of upholding precepts by bodhisattvas, the practice of upholding precepts that embraces all wholesome dharmas, the practice of upholding precepts that does not abandon seeking good and virtuous friends, the practice of upholding precepts that protects and embraces the wondrous Dharma, the practice of upholding precepts that is always for the benefit of others, the practice of upholding precepts that dedicates to great enlightenment, the practice of upholding precepts that always enters samÄdhi in tranquility, and the practice of upholding precepts that cuts off afflictions and the habits of afflictions.
Good man!

The bodhisattvas are well able to discern the subtle and secret precepts. For this reason, the precepts that those bodhisattvas cultivate and uphold cannot be known by those who lack the wisdom of all modes. This is called the power of practicing precepts by the bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas.
Good man!

The bodhisattva sees that suffering is only a collection, false, insubstantial, and without a life-force. This is called knowing the collection.

The bodhisattva knows that suffering does not come from the primordial limit, does not reach the future limit, and does not abide in the present limit. It is beginningless and endless, its essence is originally quiescent, its essence is empty, and its essence is tranquil. Knowing it in this way is called knowing cessation.
It was asked:
What is the dharma that is called cessation?
It was answered:
Good man!
That which is extinguished cannot be spoken of.
He asked:
Good man!
If that which is extinguished cannot be spoken of, why is it said to be extinguished?
He replied:
Good man!

Speaking of extinction refers to the unreal dharmas of guest afflictions and hindrances, which are falsely discriminated. Bodhisattvas do not discriminate those unreal dharmas, and at that time it can be said that they attain the extinction of extinction.
But false dharmas are originally non-existent and cannot be extinguished. Therefore the TathÄgata says that all dharmas are originally quiescent and extinguished.
He asked:
Good man!
The TathÄgata says that bodhisattvas do not realize extinction. If bodhisattvas realize extinction, they would fall into the stage of Å›rÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas.
Why did the TathÄgata say this?
He replied:
Good man!
Realization is called direct perception.
But the dharma of extinction cannot be directly perceived. Therefore the TathÄgata says that the dharma of extinction cannot be seen.
If a dharma is not seen, that dharma is also not realized.
Therefore, the TathÄgata says that the bodhisattva does not see cessation and does not realize cessation.
Based on this meaning, the TathÄgata says that the bodhisattva does not realize cessation.
The Å›rÄvakas realize cessation because they grasp at the characteristics of dharmas.
Knowing by what kind of mindfulness, what kind of contemplation, what kind of practice, thus knowing, thus seeing, thus determining, is called knowing the path.
Furthermore, good man!
What is called suffering is called self.
If that self has characteristics, thus accumulating is called knowing accumulation.
The bodhisattva sees that accumulation, does not see a single dharma that can accumulate, thus knowing is called knowing cessation.
If one can thus contemplate, if one can thus seek, it is called knowing the path.
Furthermore, good man!
Wherever there is a mind attached to dharmas, that is called suffering.
Why is it so?
Good man!
The TathÄgata always says:
Following the mind's attachments is called suffering, and the place where the mind is attached is unreal.
Therefore, the arising of suffering from the mind's attachments is called the accumulation;
The non-attachment of suffering to the mind is called cessation.
By what kind of wisdom is that wisdom not attached? It is called the path.
Good man!
I can now explain based on the wisdom of the four noble truths. If bodhisattvas were to speak for an eon or countless eons, it would be inexhaustible.

When this wisdom of the four noble truths was spoken, 60,000 bodhisattvas cultivated the wisdom perfumed by the four noble truths and attained the stage of nonretrogression.
